abstracts.cdata!:
The GEF Wetlands Restoration and
            Pollution Reduction Project will assist in the restoration
            of wetlands in the Danube River basin and pilot the use of
            riparian wetlands as nutrient traps. Since this is the first
            project of its kind, it should be well-designed,
            environmentally sound, and socially acceptable so that it
            can be a model for similar development in the future. This
            environmental assessment concludes that firstly, the
            wetlands restoration may not lead to the expected increase
            in fish resources. A technical solution is proposed to
            ensure an annual flooding for around 60 days which would be
            sufficient for successful spawning of fish and for inflowing
            of significant volumes of water from the Danube to be
            treated by the water vegetation. Secondly, risk of negative
            impacts by flooding and groundwater on arable and non-arable
            land, buildings, and drainage structures is considered very
            high. A compensation system should be agreed upon with the
            affected land owners. The technical project should stress on
            the inland protection. It should also focus on continued
            functioning of the remaining part of the drainage system to
            prevent flooding and damaging of the drainage system.
            Thirdly, increased population of mosquitoes, risk of
            malaria, and population of fish products are not expected.
            However, it is advisable to have a mosquito management plan
            using both biological and chemical control measures, and
            introduce the European standards for control of fish products.
